step.text: <html>The steps illustrated in this section occur at all of the promoters in E. coli. RNA polymerase (RNAP) is a large (Mr = 480 kDa), multisubunit enzyme. The "core" enzyme contains the catalytic site for RNA synthesis; it is shown here as a single gold-colored unit. Sigma subunit (s ) combines with core to form the holoenzyme. Sigma is responsible for recognizing the DNA sequences in the -35 and -10 regions.</html>

<html>The initial (reversible) binding of RNAP at the promoter results in the formation of a "closed complex". The second step results in DNA strand separation from about -12bp to +2bp relative to the transcription start point (+1). The "open complex" thus formed is then committed to the transcription process.</html>

<html>Triphosphates (rNTPs) bind in a template-directed order and are polymerized from 5' to 3'. Each triphosphate contributes one nucleotide unit to the mRNA. Phosphodiester bond formation is catalyzed by RNAP with the release of inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi). When the RNA chain is about 10-12 nucleotides long, sigma subunit dissociates, leaving the core enzyme to finish the RNA chain.</html>

<html>Chain elongation occurs rapidly (~50 nucleotides/sec) and processively through all three genes of the operon.
[As soon as the ribosome binding site of lac Z is accessible, ribosomes attach and begin to synthesize the b-galactosidase enzyme (not shown here, but details can be viewed in another animation).]</html>

<html>The E. coli Rho protein (r) assists RNA chain termination in many transcription units. Rho binds to segments of RNA about 70 nucleotides long that are not complexed by ribosomes. Thus, after RNAP proceeds beyond the last lac gene (A), Rho can bind to the RNA. In addition, Rho is an RNA helicase, i.e. it uses the energy of ATP hydrolysis to move (5'-> 3') along the RNA. The Rho helicase action results in the removal of the RNA from the transcribing complex and the dissociation of core enzyme from the DNA.The core enzyme can then rebind sigma to form holoenzyme and begin another transcription cycle.</html>
